Kronus

They're completely unrelated. Mauna Loa won't go off with a bang whenever that may be, it just gushes.

 
 I think you're thinking of Mauna Kea, the currently active volcano. Mauna Loa is the other big volcano on the big island, and isn't currently active, although it is showing signs of waking up. I don't think we can predict at this point how it will behave when it does go off.
Kuato

Since the Hawai'ian volcanos erupt most consistently, I'd bet that they'll be the next ones to go.
 
 The geology in Hawai'i is such that no great pressure buildup occurs, so we can't expect a huge explosion a-la Krakatoa.
 
 
 I also heard that Mount St. Helens is getting a bulge on the side, and the -ologists involved are thinking that it will indeed blow within a few years.
sinjin

I think you're thinking of Mauna Kea, the currently active volcano. Mauna Loa is the other big volcano on the big island, and isn't currently active, although it is showing signs of waking up. I don't think we can predict at this point how it will behave when it does go off.

I was just reading about volcanoes and i found a piece on Mt. Fuji so i looked it up. There is no sign of an explosion for a few years but the number of under ground quakes has grown recently, and volcanologists are starting to worry.
 
 SEE: http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/09/12/tech/main572992.shtml
OccamsRazor

The geology in Hawai'i is such that no great pressure buildup occurs, so we can't expect a huge explosion a-la Krakatoa.
 

 
 Krakatoa wasn't an explosive eruption in the sense of overpressure from magma buildup like 1981 Mt St Helens was.
 
 Basically, fissures opened up allowing seawater to penetrate into the magma chamber.... and you can imagine how much steam 1000 degrees C magma and a few million gallons of water make. Then said steam cannot escape and the thing goes boom!
 
 As far as volcano paranoia goes, the only ones that really worry me are the likes of the Yellowstone Caldera.
 
 If that thing went bang we would all (i.e. everyone on the planet) be in for a tough time.
